Introduction and purpose

Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (MSEFT) recognises the value of its workforce and is committed to support staff to provide high quality patient care. The Trust recognises and acknowledges that a flexible, efficient, and robust rostering Policy and Healthroster system is required to balance the ever changing service requirements whilst supporting staff to achieve an appropriate work life balance.
The purpose of this document is to ensure the effective utilisation of MSEFT's workforce through efficient and fair rostering by:
Ensuring safe and appropriate staffing for all services is provided by using fair and consistent rosters within the available budget.
Minimising clinical risk associated with the level and skill mix of clinical and non-clinical staffing levels
Provide effective management of establishments to optimising utilisation of clinical workforce across all wards and services
Reducing administrative tasks from clinical workforce to improve Releasing Time to Care opportunities
Improve sickness monitoring and absence in wards, services and individuals by generating comparisons, identifying trends and priorities for action.
Improve planning of non-clinical working days, e.g., annual and study leave.
Effective use of bank and agency staff and reduce bank and agency spending costs, whilst improving continuity of care by providing managers with clear visibility of staff contracted hours
Providing a mechanism for reporting against key performance indicators (KPIs) see appendix 3, for Safe Staffing and the Trust in general

Effective use of the system helps support visibility and transparency of clinical judgements and accurate information on staffing and re-deployment of staff: In particular, the policy sets out how the Trust intends to: Ensure safe and appropriate staffing levels for all departments using fair and consistent rosters, alongside SafeCare.
Support the required number of in-patient beds is safely staffed to meet elective and emergency demand.
Supporting staff to maintain an effective work-life balance
Ensure that when an adverse staffing situation occurs a standard approach is taken to assess, manage and mitigate the impact of the risk of the situation
Ensure compliance with WTD
Scope
This procedure is applicable to all areas of the Trust and applies to all staff using HealthRoster, Employee Online and Bank Staff.
Roles and responsibilities
Chief Executive, Executive Board and Directors

Trust Boards will take full responsibility for the quality of care provided to patients, and as a key determinant of quality, take full and collective responsibility for nursing, midwifery and care staffing capacity and capability, National Quality Board (NQB) (2013)

To meet this requirement and in line with the recommendations of the NQB the Trust Board will receive a monthly report, analysing the planned versus actual of clinical and non-clinical hours worked, set against the agreed key performance indicators, by ward/clinical area with explanation being provided where there is a negative variance between planned and actual hours worked.
In addition, the Trust Board will receive six-monthly report that will review the skill mix within the Trust by ward and clinical areas.
The Chief Executive, Executive Board and Directors are responsible for:
Supporting the implementation of this policy.
Championing the ongoing success of the policy.
Ensuring appropriate financial resource.
Service Directors, Divisional Managers and Heads of Nursing Service Directors and Heads of Nursing are responsible for:
Reviewing, monitoring, and reporting against KPIs and reporting through the organisation's Rostering Performance Management Framework.
Providing guidance and support to Unit / Department Managers or designated staff in the creation of duty rosters, using the KPIs as a reference.
Developing intervention and recovery plans for units, wards and departments failing to meet KPIs.
Approval and finalisation of rosters, in line with the respective calendar deadlines for each period.
Service Managers and Matrons
Service Managers and Matrons are responsible for the higher-level approvals in the HealthRoster system including:
Liaising with the Finance Business Partners on additional hours agreed above the required staffing resource.
Supporting the Unit Manager in the creation of rosters, particularly in relation to the KPIs and best practice guidance.
Approving or rejecting requests in accordance with this policy and the roster calendar.
Requests for staffing should be forwarded to temporary staffing once roster fully approved.
Unit Managers (Ward Manager/Department Manager/Line Manager)
Unit Managers are responsible for ensuring policy implementation and compliance within their areas of responsibility.

Several reports can be produced by Healthroster to support performance management. These reports outlined in appendix 6 should be generated monthly by Senior Matrons or Service Managers for distribution monthly and review at relevant Directorate Meetings.
Ensure the demands of the service are being met in conjunction with KPIs.
Produce and monitor reports on staffing, expenditure, and adherence to roster policy.
Ensure that the use of temporary staff is in line with the Trust's guidelines for use of Bank, Agency and Locum staff; subject to review according to operational pressures.
Provide guidance and support in the creation of rosters, using the KPIs as a reference.
Liaising with the Finance Business Partner of any additional hours agreed above the required staffing establishment.
Ensure compliance and publication of the roster.
Support staff with roster training requirements.
Liaising with HR, Finance and Erostering team to update demand templates, staffing establishments, personal patterns, and skill mix.
All staff members are represented on the roster with their agreed hours of working.
The roster is maintained and is an accurate representation of what has been worked.
All shifts that require temporary staffing cover are passed to the Trust's temporary staffing team at the earliest opportunity, to avoid short notice requests.
Ensure equality of opportunity for staff to obtain access to additional hours.
Ensure their team has more than one staff member able to create the roster to ensure that the guidelines stipulated in this policy can be always adhered to.
Please ensure approval and finalisation of rosters are in line with the respective calendar deadlines for each period.
Roster creators

The roster creator is responsible for creating the roster, ensuring all department requirements are met including staff requests. The roster creator is responsible to the unit manager and should ensure the following principles are applied:
Ensure updates are cascaded appropriately to staff.
Ensure that the roster creator has an appropriate amount of planned protected time is available to complete the roster.
Use the AutoRoster facility wherever possible to ensure the optimum rosters are created quickly.
Ensure a fair and equitable roster is created with taking into considerations staff requests.

Ensure the roster is created to minimise the use of temporary staff, taking into consideration any fluctuations of service requirements, and ensuring an adequate skill mix to maintain patient and staff safety.
Liaise with trainers, coordinators, and mentors to ensure student and rotational placement dates and appropriate supervisors are assigned.
Roster maintainers
Roster Maintainers are responsible for keeping the roster up to date and accurate following roster approval (publication).
Ensuring all shift updates are made as soon as possible.
Ensuring all absences are recorded at the earliest possible convenience, including sickness and emergency leaves.
To make requests for temporary staffing if required.
Rota co-ordinators (medical rotas)
Rota Co-ordinators are responsible for building and maintaining their Service's medical rota in Erostering.

In the lead up to the staffing rotations, the rota co-ordinator will give the Erostering team the new personal working plans including Direct Clinical Care (DCC) and Supporting Professional Activities (SPA). and will be provided with as much notice as possible.
Creating the rota in Erostering, to consider cover for planned leave.
Ensuring all absences are recorded at the earliest possible convenience, including sickness and emergency leaves.
All individuals / users
All users of the Erostering systems should ensure that they abide by the following principles:
Use learning resources to develop familiarity with rostering tools, attending rostering training, as required by line managers.
Check that the personal information and hours worked are accurate as stated on the roster and raise any inaccuracies to line managers immediately.
Request duty, study leave and annual leave using the Employee Online toolkit (which is more efficient than paper and provides a strong audit trail for monitoring fairness).
Being reasonable and flexible with their roster requests and considerate to their colleagues within the guidelines set out by the Trust.
A maximum of 4 duty requests can be made for a roster period. This is pro- rata for part time staff as shown in the table below.

data.text: Attending work as per their duty roster.
Request for any duty changes after the roster is published, must be discussed with their line Manager.
It must not be assumed by staff that the roster can be changed to accommodate ad-hoc requests as service requirements will take priority. Requests will be considered in light of the service needs.

Staff are responsible for negotiating their own changes once the roster has been fully approved by the manager and any changes or swapping of shifts must be notified to the line manager, and these must be kept to a minimum.

This does not mean unexpected events and personal emergencies cannot be accommodated, but these issues must be discussed with unit managers at the time and managerial discretion will apply to requests where appropriate – in line with Trust policy.
Erostering team
The Erostering team are responsible for maintaining the rostering systems, assisting managers to maintain accurate rosters, and responding to staff enquiries by:
Ensuring that rosters and system information is accurate and the data is maintained in order.
Delivering high quality training to managers to ensure they have the tools to utilise the Erostering systems.
Troubleshooting problems with the Erostering system, resolving and/or escalating to the software supplier/Trust IT department as appropriate.
Leading on system upgrades and developments.
Working with managers and clinicians to build effective demand templates that meet the service requirements for safety and budget.
Maintaining demand templates by reviewing them on a rolling annual basis with the unit manager, matron and Finance and HR representatives.
Running the monthly payroll extracts (for attendance and absence) in line with the Trust agreed deadlines.
Responding to users (staff and managers) queries and resolve requests in line with the agreed standards.
Erostering Operational Group

The Trust's Erostering Operational group is responsible for monitoring the operation of this policy and for providing analytical reports on strategic and operational compliance with roster management KPIs.
Human Resources (HR)
The HR team is responsible for supporting the Erostering team in keeping the rostering system updated with accurate information.
By Maintaining HR system with accurate information so that information can be reliably transferred into the Erostering system.
By Assisting Erostering team and managers with queries relating to Agenda for Change contracts.
Finance
The finance team is responsible for supporting the Erostering team in keeping the rostering system updated with accurate information.
By providing the rostering team with updated cost-centres.
By providing rostering team with updated budget figures and budgeted WTEs for the departments.
Types of roster
There are three basic approaches to rostering that apply to different types of service:
Dynamic rostering
These are situations when the work demand (usually clinical) demonstrates a high degree of variation and needs active management and monitoring (e.g., acute care setting).
Dynamic rosters need to be well-planned, approved in advance and need to be maintained for sickness and other absence as close as possible to real time.
Activity-based rosters
These are situations when the work demand is capable of being planned/scheduled (e.g., into clinic or theatre sessions).
While work might still be very intense, is more predictable in relation to the assessed time demand.
Activity-based rosters need to be well-planned, approved in advance and need to be maintained for sickness and other absence as close as possible to real time.
Fixed rosters
These are situations where work is organised around the contracted set of work patterns of existing staff.
Some clinical areas and most support functions demonstrate these features.
Fixed rosters may not require approval in advance but still need to be maintained for sickness and other absence as close as possible to real time.
Production and approval of rosters – Trust requirements
Basic requirements
The roster will cover a 4-week period, resulting in  rosters annually – a set timetable will be published by the Erostering team.

Rosters will automatically open  days prior to the start date of the roster period for duty requests, as long as roster templates have been opened by manager/roster creator, in the absence of the manager/roster creator HealthRoster can action this.
Rosters will automatically close 42 days (6 weeks) prior to the start date of the roster period for duty requests.
All rosters will commence on a Monday. Creation and approval
The designated person for each area/department is responsible for compiling the roster.
Auto rosters should be used where possible to minimise manual rostering.
All rosters will be fully approved before they are published to staff.

The roster will be prepared and must be fully approved and published (published) at least 6weeks in advance to the start of the roster period in accordance with the Trust's Roster Publication timetable (refer to Appendix 1) except where individual exceptions have been agreed.
Rosters are validated using the following workflow:
The prospective roster period is created and reviewed by the unit manager.
During the initial review process, using Roster Analyser, the proposed operational metrics should be validated for roster safety and effectiveness (refer to Appendix 3).
Once deemed acceptable, the unit manager will 1st level approve the 4-week period, referred to as “partial approval”.
The partially approved roster is then validated by the Service Manager/Matron or appropriate approver for ratification. The 2nd level approver can either reject or approve a proposed roster.
If rejected, the roster should be revisited by the unit manager and reworked in line with Senior Manager feedback.
If approved, the roster is then published to unit staff for viewing and the period is confirmed as planned.
Operational leads must complete roster approval within one week, after which further escalation will be made to the Deputy Chief Nurse, Chief Nurse or Associate Director if non-Nursing roster.
An exception report will be produced against the KPI's and poor compliance with roster approval will be escalated to Senior Management.
Competencies, safety and skills mix
It is the manager's responsibility to ensure safe skill mix of staff within the department/area.
Each area should have an agreed level of staff with specific competencies which reflects the nature of skill required within the department.
All rosters should be created to utilise permanent staff proportionately across all shifts or within a time frame to suit the service needs of the department.
Management, clerical, or support staff should be entered onto the rosters as appropriate.
Fair shift times, breaks and rest periods

Shift/duty start times are to be determined by local management who should seek to ensure that where service delivery can be improved by standardisation across departments and sites is achieved wherever possible.
Ward Matrons, Operational Managers or Nurses in Charge are responsible for ensuring that breaks are facilitated, and rest periods are adhered to.
Break time must be included in all shifts over six hours as a standard. A 30-minute break is a minimum requirement in any orientation, on a shift longer than 6 hours.

Break times on shifts that are  hours or longer are required to have a 60-minute break, in any orientation. Trust breaks are unpaid unless superseded by any agreed National contract terms e.g., 2016 Junior Doctors Contract, or placement staff.

Any shifts that have the break time removed in the roster will highlight with a warning in accordance with the Working Time Regulations. It is the responsibility of the line manager to ensure all breaks are taken in a timely fashion. Staff should not substitute their breaks for the option of late arrival or early departure as the purpose of the break is to provide rest time during the shift. Under certain situation; for example if a member of staff is scrubbed in theatres from 8 am and the case finishes at 6:30 pm. The staff shift finishes at 6 pm. Not only the staff didn't have lunch but also has gone  minutes over. Your roster will need to be updated to show the correct pattern, which is the standard approach entering this data on eroster. Change of staff in the middle of surgery is not best practice due to safety

Long shifts must be no longer than  hours, including a 60-minute unpaid break (i.e.,  paid hours). This would be the maximum length allowable for a day or night shift. A long shift is defined as any shift greater than eight hours in length.

Working a shift time change: Any staff member will receive the associated unsocial enhancement in their pay for time worked and hours worked will account toward their contracted hours for that roster.
Breaks must not be planned to be taken at the end of the shift as their purpose is to provide rest time during the shift.
These regulations have been set as global rules in HealthRoster and will be adhered to when setting up shifts for units. For further information on the above, refer to Working Time Regulations.
Nursing and support rostering principles
For departments with variable shift patterns (typically applies to both nursing and support services providing care 24 hours a day/7 day a week):
Nursing rosters must always have a designated senior member of staff/nurse in charge of each shift who is easily identifiable on the roster.
Staff may be required to work a variety of shifts and shift patterns as agreed by their department manager to fulfil the service.
Shifts should be assigned to maximise work/life balance and staff well-being, such as, grouping days off together and keeping nights together where possible.

Staff should not work more than three long shifts in succession or four nights in succession and should have a minimum of two days off after being rostered for a night shift, commonly represented as 1 sleep day and 1 full day off.

It is anticipated that a combination of different shift lengths will be worked by staff to complete 150 hours of work over a four-week roster period (for full time staff). Where this is not the case as a matter of routine, additional shifts, or time off needs to be planned to bring the employee's hours back into balance.

It is not possible to write off hours owing without the Approval of Service Directors and Finance. In all instances where an hour's balance is as a result of an error in record, the roster should be corrected.

All working time should be recorded accurately and literally, to ensure time and attendance reflects work done. This is a requirement for compliance with EWTD, Health and Safety and for appropriate pay remuneration.
Line managers should not regularly be rostered to work night, bank holiday or weekend shifts. Occasional working during this period to monitor the quality of care and workload demands is expected.
Where staff work predominantly night shifts, they may be required to rotate to a day shifts for professional development.
Staff deployment

During staff shortages it is accepted that staff may be required to work in other clinical areas to provide a safe and efficient service. Senior Matrons or Service Managers for each area are responsible for the deployment of staff within the area or service to meet service requirements. During Out of hours, this decision will be made by identified senior staff on duty who may escalate to management on call if required. Movements of staff between units needs to be reflected on HealthRoster, e.g., staff were scheduled to work an Early on one unit but ended up doing an Early on another unit to ensure actual staff numbers and hours data is accurate for Safe Staffing reporting.

It is recognised that occasionally staffing needs to be viewed as a whole, i.e., cross- hospital or cross-service when staffing redeployment in a hospital or service is not possible. In these instances, Senior Matrons or Service Managers are responsible for working with Heads of Hospital or Service to make final decisions as to which clinical staff can be redeployed taking into account all ward and service dependencies. Again, these movements need to be reflected on HealthRoster.

It is accepted that in the event of a Major Incident; staff will be redeployed, taking into consideration their skills and competencies, to provide the best patient care. The Healthroster system will be used to manage workforce redeployment in the event of a major incident.
Medical rostering principles

Consultant rotas will be agreed during the job planning process, once confirmed, the sessions will be assigned on their Erostering. Confirmed job plans are indicative of a Consultants commitment to an expected service delivery over a minimum of 42 weeks.

Job plans are the key driver to the planning of other additional clinical workforce and therefore should be maintained with a high degree of accuracy. Recording, amended, or additional demand to activities or any absence will impact other resource and should be reflected on rostering as soon as possible to do so.
Medical rosters must have a designated primary person who is responsible for Direct Clinical Care easily identifiable on the roster.
Junior doctor rosters will be created to ensure compliance and required service cover.
Rosters Coordinators will complete the detailed rota plan eight weeks in advance, so the clinician's availability is confirmed for other activity and rota planning.
The rosters should be updated in Erostering to maintain accuracy and cover plans.
Adverse staffing situations
When planning rosters, Unit Managers may identify situations where an adverse staffing situation looks unavoidable.
Unit Managers, Service Managers and Matrons need to assess clinical staffing situations.

Adjustments to the planned roster will usually be required to address and prevent or mitigate an identified Adverse Staffing Situation. Such situations need formal approval of Service Managers or Matrons and require a formal risk assessment based on professional clinical judgements. Changes must be made in agreement with staff once a roster has been fully approved.
The process for escalation and management of adverse staffing levels can be found in SOPN001 for Mitigation Actions in Response to Acuity Red Flags (Safe Staffing) (refer to appendix 2).
The risk assessment should be documented using the Trust's Risk management policy.

data.text: Working time regulations
Working hours rules
The Trust has set up the rules of rostering to ensure compliance with the Working Time Regulations:

Staff must not work more than an average of 48 hours over a  week (26 weeks for Medical) reference period. The total of 48 average hours worked includes all hours worked (i.e., substantive, dual/bank/agency working and study leave).

All shifts greater than six hours in length must include a 30-minute unpaid break, to be taken at a time agreed with the line manager. Staff working a shift exceeding ten consecutive hours in length will have a minimum of 60 minutes unpaid break time during their shift. This may be taken as one block or in separate blocks.

Breaks must be taken during a shift and are not to be taken at the beginning or end of a shift (e.g., starting later or finishing earlier) as the purpose is to provide rest time during the duty. Staff may rest in designated rooms within their break period but must return to the clinical area to work at the set time.

The maximum number of consecutive long day duties (including Bank duties) recommended for staff to work is  All staff are entitled to a daily rest period of 11 hours between shifts, unless emergency on-call or standby arrangements mean that an exception must be made to meet an unforeseen service demand.

All staff are entitled to a weekly rest period of either  hours within a seven- day period, 48 hours within a 14-day period, or two periods of 24 hours within 14 days. The weekly rest period should not include the daily rest period entitlement of 11 hours;however, on-call may vary.

The roster system will display a violation when an average of 48 hours over a 17 week period (26 weeks for Medical) has been rostered to prevent the future planning of WTD breaching shifts. Where a breach has occurred and is required to be recorded, please contact the HealthRoster team. WTD breaches are reported in the operational KPIs, it is the responsibility of Service Managers manager to monitor breaches, review the frequency of breaches and determine any rectifications needed.
A maximum ofhours per week can be worked in any working week, via any combination of working contract (Bank and Substantive).

Night shifts must include a 60-minute unpaid break. The Nurse in Charge / Team leader is responsible for ensuring that breaks are facilitated. If breaks are unable to be taken at an agreed time (due to clinical need), they should be taken as soon after this point as possible or a note made on the duty.
Sleeping within clinical and public areas on Trust premises on any duty is not allowed. Staff must return to the clinical area to work at the set time.
Opting out
It is possible for individuals to sign an Opt-Out from the requirements of the Working Time Regulations.
Staff can only opt out of the average hours, not the minimum rest period.
It is Trust policy that an opt-out:
Lasts for a 12-month period.
Requires a risk assessment and review to be undertaken on each application.
Should be recorded on the Eroster.

A copy of the Opt-Out Form should be saved in the local personnel file and sent to HR and the Erostering team. Historic opt out forms may need to be provided, so do retain these for future reference. (See appendix 4).
Night workers
Managers must identify if there are special hazards faced by night workers by identifying them in risk assessments, as involving a significant risk to health and safety.
Young Workers
A young worker is defined in employment legislation as a person aged 16 or
A young worker must not work for more than eight hours per day and  hours per week. These hours cannot be averaged out.
Young workers are entitled to:
An unpaid 30-minute break every 4 ½ hours.
A rest period of 12 hours between working days.
Two days off per week.
Young workers may not work at night between 22:00 and 06:00 because of UK employment legislation.
SafeCare data entry and analysis
For units delivering acute care in ward environments, the SafeCare tool supports decision-making on staffing levels based on assessed patient acuity at standard census points during each day.
In units deploying SafeCare, patient acuity data must be entered onto SafeCare for the agreed Census Periods each day.
It is the responsibility of the Nurse in Charge / Rota Co-ordinator to ensure that it is entered for each Census Period as per the agreed time frames.
The data can be entered by any individual who has the appropriate access to the system.
The patient acuity data should be entered between  minutes prior to the start of the Census Period and  minutes after the start of the Census Period.
All data entered prior to the 1-hour window will be considered as predictive.
Data entry is monitored by Ward Managers and Matrons to ensure that all data is entered, and where relevant challenge the levels of a patient's acuity.
Booking of temporary staff
Substantive staff must be given priority and allocated shifts prior to temporary staff being allocated or booked.
A Trust employed staff must be on duty in any given area or department.
Unfilled shifts should be reported to the temporary staffing office once the roster has been fully approved to facilitate efficient workforce planning.
Finalisation of Bank duties should be completed by the Department manager or nominated responsible party as soon as possible after the shift is completed to ensure the work time recorded is accurate.
Bank shifts should only be cancelled via the bank team as there is a defined process to mitigate double bookings and associated costs – see temporary staffing policy for this process.

No replacement staff should be booked without the line manager or designated deputy assessing the need for them, the grade that is required and the time that they will be required to start and finish.
The line manager or designated deputy should maintain a system to demonstrate the rationale for the usage of temporary staff within agreed minimum safe staffing levels.
Temporary staff should be deployed to high priority/hard to fill shifts in the first instance.
Authorisation for Agency support staff must be made by the Clinical site manager or Matron.
Monthly reporting is made to the Board which identifies the percentage usage of temporary staff within the Trust.

After an episode of sickness, bank staff may return when they are fit to work and should be accountable for the number of shifts, they commit to, depending on their severity of sickness and period of absence. Dual bank staff may return to work on the bank when fit to work and when agreed with the Ward/Dept manager though there may be further departmental restrictions locally.
Time off in lieu (TOIL)

Any time worked by staff over and above their contracted hours should be sanctioned by Ward Matrons or Operational Managers and recorded on Healthroster. At no time should time owing exceed a total ofhours (2-night shifts) or the equivalent of 2 days' work.

In general, it is best to identify a time or shift when time owing can be taken back, and this should be done as close as possible to the time it was actually accrued. Any time claimed back, must be authorised by Ward Matrons or Operational Managers. These hours should be allocated on Healthroster as an Other Leave – TOIL unavailability.
Managers should keep a record of hours owing/hours worked and this will be held in the system. Time off in lieu principles as outlined in Agenda for Change Terms and Conditions should be applied.
If, for operational reasons, an employee is unable to take TOIL within three months, they will be paid in accordance with Agenda for Change Terms and Conditions.(Part 3 section 3.5 NHS Handbook).
Night workers

A” night worker” is someone who works at least 50% of their shift hours during this period. This means different working patterns in units may have “night shifts” that start and finish at different times.

Line managers are responsible for ensuring that all staff working night shifts are offered a free health assessment, via our occupational health service, on a two- yearly basis, or sooner should the individual notify their manager of a change in personal circumstances.
Annual leave and bank holidays
Annual leave arrangements will be managed by the line manager or their designated deputy in accordance with the principles outlined in the following documents and policies:
MSEPO-20227 Leave Policy
Agenda for Change Terms and Conditions of Service Handbook
Employees should spread their annual leave throughout the year.

Staff have a responsibility to manage their annual leave in accordance with the annual leave policy, ensuring requests are made at least 6 weeks in advance, except in exceptional circumstances where line manager is ultimately responsible for authorising whether the annual leave can take place on the day(s) requested on the basis of achieving a reasonable balance between the needs of the service and the wishes of the employee.
Flexible working
Any requests for flexible working should be handled in accordance with the guidance detailed in the Trust's Flexible working policy.
Performance monitoring and compliance

On a routine basis, the Trust uses metrics on [Roster Authorisation and Publication, Effectiveness, Rostering Effectiveness, Rostering Budget, Fairness and Safety to assess how well managers are planning. These Metrics are included in a comparative performance report and reviewed on a quarterly basis (usually 3 roster periods).

Service Managers and Directors should review the routine performance and policy compliance of their units and ensure Unit Managers understand their responsibilities to manage and improve their rostering practice to obtain the best staffing solutions possible.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved locally by the HR Policy Working Group prior to submission to the Controlled Document team for ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the HR Policy Working Group and key staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Training
Mandatory training
There is no mandatory training associated with this protocol. Specific training not covered by mandatory training

All substantive staff receive training on Employee Online as part of e-Rostering implementation. Employee Online Quick Reference Card is available on the Hub. All Ward Matrons and Operational Managers, Senior Matrons and Service Managers and Ward and Unit Admin received role specific training as part of e-Rostering implementation.
Monitoring compliance with this document

The table below outlines the Trust's monitoring arrangements for this document. The Trust reserves the right to commission additional work or change the monitoring arrangements to meet organisational needs.

Redraft to unify the process for the newly merged organisation and included initial feedback from survey and other requirements. Included Trust specific details and confirm MSE processes and ways of working
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)

As the Healthroster systems is being merged into one instance across the organisation, standardisation of ways of working within the systems will improved management practices in planning rosters, managing staffing levels to ensure the delivery of safe and effective care within budgets
Who benefits from this change and how?

All staff and patients will benefit from the standardisation of working rostering practices with the improvement of management practices across the organisation, management of staff and their working needs and ensuring safe levels of care
